video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text: For those wondering how to stop Big Box from cupping...flip your boards over to what is going to be the bottom. Make sure all your boards fit together tight..clamp them tight..like you are doing a glue up..take your router and cut a 1/2  wide groove from side to side..NOT the length..stop about half way through the last board...go buy some rebar and use epoxy ...drop the rebar in deep enough so it's just below the surface..mix and pour in your epoxy...let set up.and dry...BAM ... done. We did this to a table we made using pine from HD..It's been outside for over 3 years...NO MOVEMENT..NO CUPPING..NO SPLITTING...

video_title: I've Never Seen A Laser Do THIS Before! - Laserpecker 2 Review
comment_text: I like the build quality and amazing attention to detail on the whole LP product range, except the L2 rollers, because gnarling is traditionally used to improving finger grip on rotary knobs, it doesn't really grip things only resting on it. It also tends to lose grip easily unlike rubberised or silicon rollers. They may look aesthetically pleasing, but in my book functionality and practicality ranks much higher.

video_title: Is it worth it?  xTool 40W Diode Laser Review
comment_text: Have some experience with 100w CO2 laser, and I was usually running engraving with 300mm/s speed. Some diode lasers are advertised to be able to run up to 24000mm/min, which is equal to 400mm/s, so theoretically they could do the same as CO2 laser. Perhaps in case of 300mm/s even 40w optical power would not be enough fo good result, but I am confused why people are not running such tests on yt - usually they go up to 10000mm/min.

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review
comment_text: I think there is a lot of nuance in getting the right laser cutter. The Polar looks like an interesting machine and I might be interested if I was getting something for my house. I'm a teacher and the Glowforge works best for my classroom. The footprint is just right for the classroom (looks similar to the Polar). The web interface is a selling point, allowing us to manage multiple users easily and not worry about software. I only use the interface to set up my cuts, where the camera is very useful. Everything else is done in Illustrator, Inkscape, or Vectornator. The subscription is completely optional and unnecessary. Respectfully, the review makes it sound almost required - that is simply incorrect. I have 5 Glowforges (the plus model). They are used constantly, the oldest being 3 years old, and I have never had a serious problem with any of them. Support was quick and helpful when an issue did present itself, the GF was cutting again by the end of the day. It is a no fuss machine - and that is what I need when working with 100 students each quarter. If I were buying a hobby machine I would have different requirements, but the Glowforge is pretty awesome for us. Just wanted to provide a different perspective/experience.

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review

video_title: ORTUR'S BEST YET! - Ortur Laser Master 3 Review
comment_text: The limit function on this kind of driver works by monitoring the amount of current the stepper draws under normal operation vs what it would draw once the motor has stalled. It is closed looped insofar as a circuit reacts to the rapid jump in current (at the speed of light) and cuts the current (steps) to the motor. This is the way it should be done, as limit switches are prone to failure at some point.

video_title: I Was Wrong About the One Laser X Desktop Laser
comment_text: I am really considering this machine for my small business that mostly includes specialized metal fabrication from welding to plasma cutting and heat treatment. I specialize in knife making, and I'm beginning to think my 45amp cnc plasma table is the best choice for cutting metal. But as for other hard materials such as exotic wood and resin, as well as engraving metal and wood, I'm trying to find the best most affordable laser to upgrade to from my 40w D1pro.

comment_text: I have same scanner, but I noticed some problem about to scan hair and beard, the Otter often do not recognize hair and beard, so I took 2 scantions, the first for total body setting and the second for only face setting and then I cutted and removed the face from the body version and I attached the face version on the body version. Tne point is that in the body version the scanner reconstruct the hir and beard but not very well, how do you reach to obtain so perfect hair and beard ?

comment_text: Great information thank you!  I have a couple of questions.  Can any of the lasers (about $1000.00) do both the color laser marking on stainless and also cut balsa wood? video_title: What is a 3D Laser Cutter?  Full Spectrum Muse 3D Review
comment_text: Checking back in on this in 2024, I have the muse Laser currently just got it about four months ago. Have had a lot of issues with it. One of those being the RE3 software and machine now requires an Internet connection by default in order for you to use the software. after contacting Support several times I was finally given a key of sorts and URL to enter said key in order to force the software local so I did not have to have a Internet connection. I just wanted to let you know speaking directly to your 02:30 takers.

video_title: Laser Companies Are Lying To You
comment_text: The 40w machine has a smaller workspace, which isn't explained to customers on the website, and the auto-conveyor system has been a huge waste of money so far.   I would recommend the 20w machine so far, but don't waste your money on the 40w or the conveyor system
